thread.title: Bay Area arts and entertainment events for week of Oct. 25

author: sfgate.com
title: Bay Area arts and entertainment events for week of Oct. 25
text:
Photo: The Zombies Image 1 of / 1 Caption
Close
Image 1 of 1 The Zombies reunite to play the Fillmore on Tuesday, Oct. 27. The Zombies reunite to play the Fillmore on Tuesday, Oct. 27. Photo: The Zombies Bay Area arts and entertainment events for week of Oct. 25 1  /  1 Back to Gallery S
DANCE
‘Arcane: A Tale of All Hallows Eve’
Celebrate the spirit and spirits of Halloween in a steampunk environment. The one-act piece from Company C Contemporary Ballet is full of surprises and ghoulish props appropriate for the entire family. Costumes are encouraged. After the final show, there is a reception where you can mix and mingle with the cast, choreographer, designers and musicians. 1 and 7 p.m. Sunday, Oct. 25; 8 p.m. Friday, Oct. 30; 1 and 7 p.m. Saturday, Oct. 31. Cowell Theater , Fort Mason, 2 Marina Blvd., San Francisco. $25-$55. (415) 392-4400, www.cityboxoffice.com. 
CONCERT/FESTIVAL 
OneBeat 
The international consortium features 25 musicians ages 19 to 35. The musicians hail from 17 countries and come together for a two-week residency to write, produce, record and perform musical works intended to shatter genres. OneBeat is an initiative of the U.S. State Department’s Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs . 2-6 p.m. Sunday, Oct. 25. Montalvo Arts Center , 15400 Montalvo Rd., Saratoga. Free. (408) 961-5858, www.montalvoarts.org. 
M
FUNDRAISER 
‘Spooked
at the Strand’
Dress in costume for this bewitching soiree that benefits American Conservatory Theater ’s actor training and education and community programs. A cocktail reception is followed by a cabaret performance by students from ACT’s master of fine arts program. After-show festivities include dancing with music by DJ Flaxo. 6-11 p.m. Monday, Oct. 26. The Strand Theater , 1127 Market St., San Francisco. $50-$500. (415) 439-2470, www.act.sf.org/spooked. 
T 
MUSIC 
The Zombies
The British psychedelic group produced some of the greatest hits of the ’60s, including, “She’s Not There,” “Time of the Season” and “Tell Her No.” The Zombies will re-create their 1968 album “Odessey and Oracle” and play new songs. The performers include original band members Colin Blunstone and Rod Argent. It’s their first American tour together in 50 years. 8 p.m. Tuesday, Oct. 27. Fillmore, 1805 Geary Blvd., San Francisco. $39.50. (800) 653-8000, www.livenation.com. 
W
CABARET 
Sharon McNight 
as Sophie Tucker 
The singer’s one-woman show celebrates Sophie Tucker. McNight resurrects some of Tucker’s greatest songs, including “There’ll Be Some Changes Made,” and “Darktown Strutters’ Ball.” McNight infuses her tribute with the same lively banter and bawdy jokes that Tucker used in nightclubs and films. 8 p.m. Wednesday-Thursday, Oct. 28-29. Feinstein’s at the Nikko, 222 Mason St., San Francisco. $25-$40. (866) 663-1063, www.ticketweb.com. 

T
LECTURE 
Brian Selznick
The Caldecott Medal winner talks about his new book, “The Marvels.” Selznick is the author of “Wonderstruck” and “The Invention of Hugo Cabret,” source of the movie “Hugo.” “The Marvels” starts with an illustrated account of Billy Marvel , who is shipwrecked and taken to London in 1766, then tells the tale of Billy’s descendants in words alone. 7 p.m. Thursday, Oct. 29. Throckmorton Theatre , 142 Throckmorton Ave., Mill Valley. $38 (includes signed book). (415) 927-0960, www.bookpassage.com. 
F
THEATER 
‘Sail Away’
Noel Coward ’s cheeky musical takes place on a Mediterranean cruise, where a brazen American ex-actress working as a cruise director on a British ship is drawn into an affair with a passenger. 7 p.m. Wednesday-Thursday, Oct. 28-29; 8 p.m. Friday, Oct. 30; 6 p.m. Saturday, Oct. 31; 3 p.m. next Sunday, Nov. 1. Through Nov. 15. The Eureka Theatre , 215 Jackson St., San Francisco. $25-$75. (415) 255-8207, www.42ndstmoon.org. 
S
SPOOKY FILM/MUSIC 
‘The Rocky Horror Picture Show’
Celebrate Halloween with a 40th anniversary screening of “The Rocky Horror Picture Show” and all the scary music you can handle. The evening kicks off with the San Francisco Symphony performing music from “Psycho,” “The Exorcist,” “Poltergeist” and other spooky classics. Theremin player Dorit Chrysler plays music from the movie “Ed Wood.” A theremin is an electronic instrument played without touching it. Peaches Christ is your host. Costumes are encouraged. 7:30 p.m. Saturday, Oct. 31. Davies Symphony Hall, 201 Van Ness Ave., San Francisco. $15-$65. (415) 864-6000, www.sfsymphony.org. 
THEATER 
‘Vanya and Sonia and Masha 
and Spike’
Center REPertory Company presents a madcap mashup about siblings Vanya and Sonia, whose lives are routine and dull. Everything changes when their sister, Masha, a fading movie star, shows up with her new boy toy to make a big announcement. 7:30 p.m. Tuesday-Wednesday, Oct. 27-28; 8 p.m. Thursday-Saturday, Oct. 29-31; 2:30 p.m. next Sunday, Nov. 1. Through Nov. 21. Center REPertory Company, 1601 Civic Dr., Walnut Creek. $33-$53. (925) 943-7469, www.centerrep.org. 
— Kathleen Dixon
